Abstract
This review (with 86 refs.) covers the state of the art in electrochemical and optical immunoassay of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). The purpose of the review is to provide useful insights in terms of (a) choice of materials, (b) methods/techniques preferably applied, (c) immunological procedures, (d) immobilization procedures, and (d) other practical aspects. Following an introduction into the field, we give a short account on the principle and general types of immunoassay, and then treat immunoassay for CEA. The first section covers nanomaterial based electrochemical immunoassay, with subsections on using of nanoparticles, hyperbranched polymers, graphene and their derivatives for detection of CEA. A further large section covers photoelectrochemical immunoassay, with assays based on the use of various kinds of nanoparticles, also in combination with carbonaceous nanomaterials, or using upconversion nanoparticles, graphene quantum dots, and other nanomaterials of interest. The next large section covers optical immunoassay, with examples on assays based on the use of various kinds of conventional nanoparticles (quantum dots), upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs), graphenes and their derivatives. The review also covers aspects of surface modifications, the effect of nanostructure properties on sensing performance, and the applications of these nanomaterials in conjunction with different kind of signal transducers.
Keywords: cancer; immunoassay, immunosensor; tumor biomarkers; carcinoembryonic antigen; nanomaterial
1. Introduction
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is an important tumor biomarker for colorectal and some other carcinomas and its assay is widely accepted in the oncology practice as a useful and cost-effective tool for monitoring colon cancer after surgery. As a stable molecule, CEA is one of the most widely used tumor biomarkers and a prognostic indicator in clinical assays. CEA should be minimal in the blood of healthy adults whereas an abnormal level of CEA may be a sign of cancer, especially colon and rectal cancer [1]. CEA may also be present in patients with pancreas, liver, breast, ovary, or lung cancer. Therefore, the CEA level measured before and after surgery indicates the surgical success and the prognosis of patient's recovery. CEA levels may also be measured during chemotherapy to evaluate the treatment progress and outcome. Extensive efforts have been devoted to the determination of CEA based on the various methods such as thermal lens microscope [2], fluorescence immunoassay [3], chemiluminescence immunoassay [4], surface-enhanced Raman scattering immunoassay [5] and electrochemical immunoassay [6-8] and so forth. Among them, electrochemical and optical immunosensors have recently gained increasing attention in the quantitative detection of CEA owing to low cost, fast response, and ease of handling and miniaturization. This article reviews recent advances in the electrochemical and optical immunosensors of CEA. It is important to point out that, due to the explosion of publications in this active field, we do not claim that this review includes all of the published works in the past years and we apologize to the authors of excellent work, which is unintentionally left out. Therefore, based on the selected latest research articles from 2000 to 2016, application of electrochemical and optical immunosensors for detection of CEA was discussed and summarized in this review. This review is meant to provide an overview of the application of nanomaterials in electrochemical and optical immunosensing of CEA, along with significant advances over the last several years in related technologies. In addition, this review described:
• Most frequently applied principles in immunoassay/immunosensing of CEA • The aspects of fabrication in the perspective of immunoassay/immunosensing
applications • The potential of various electrochemical, photoelectrochemical, and optical
immunosensors for the determination of CEAwithin sub-nanomolar range and the circumvention of the most serious problem in immunosensing will be discussed. • Some of multiplex electrochemical immunosensors have been discussed with and without labels. • We also summarize the latest developments in the applications of immunoassay/immunosensing methods for detection of CEAin real samples. • The development trends of, electrochemical, photoelectrochemical, electrochemiluminescence and eroptical based immunosensors are also introduced, including newly developed integrated immunosensors, and the application of nanotechnology and microfluidic technology.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nanomaterial based electrochemical immunosensors
sections.text:
There is continuing demand for fast, simple analytical methods for the determination of many clinical, biochemical and environmental analytes. In this respect, immunoassay and immunosensors that rely on antibody-antigen interactions provide a promising means of analysis due to their specificity and sensitivity. Electrochemical immunosensors and immunoassay have recently attracted considerable interest because of their high sensitivity, low cost, and inherent small size [9, 10]. For immunosensors, the immunologic materials are
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
5
immobilized on an electrochemical transducer. The emergence of nanotechnology is opening up new horizons for the use of nanomaterial labels for signal amplification in electrochemical immunosensors [11-15]. Electrochemical immunosensors are usually obtained through the immobilization of a recognition element (i.e. antigen or antibody) on the electrode surface. The assay steps often end with the injection of a secondary enzyme-labelled antibody which follows the addition of a proper enzymatic substrate. In an electrochemical format the enzymatic reaction leads to the production of a molecule which is electroactive (that is, it gives an electrochemical signal in presence of certain inputs). The signal is recorded with the use of bench or portable instruments which are usually capable of applying different electrochemical techniques. In the case of electrochemical immunosensing of CEA, use of advanced nanomaterials (carbon based materials, (gold/silver/upconversation) nanoparticles, and hyperbranched nanopolymers) and different EC methods for improvement of electrochemical performances was discussed. Also, we summarized below examples of nanostructured material applications in electrochemical immunosensing of CEA in reported so far in the literature, with their advantages and limitations, and their potential for future development in this field was stressed. Therefore, major focus of this review is on role of nanomaterials in immunosensing of CEA. With the selected latest research articles from 2000 to September 2016, we summarized various electrochemical immunosensors for detection of CEA in this section of review. More importantly, we discussed in detail different aspects such as type of nanomaterials, injection and detection techniques, labels, analytes and the corresponding sample matrix, and sensitivity. Consequently, we discussed several outstanding properties of the electrochemical immunosensors for detection of CEA and their research opportunities as well as the development potential and prospects.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Nanoparticles (NPs)
sections.text: Nanoparticles are of great interest in the world of nanoscience based on their physical and chemical properties. Such properties offer excellent prospects for chemical and biological sensing [16]. NPs were widely used in recent years as useful, sensitive tools for the electronic, optical, and microgravimetric transduction of different biomolecular recognition events [17]. NPs can therefore be seriously enhanced by incorporating them within biological systems. The signal enhancement associated with the use of NP-amplifying labels and with the formation of NP-biomolecule assemblies provides the basis for sensitive electrical and optical detection. Such procedures couple the extensive features of NP-biomolecule associations with sensitive electrochemical or optical transduction. In general, NP-based immunosensors offer excellent potential for diagnostics and can have a deep impact upon bio-analytical applications. In this subsection, we discuss application of some NPs to electrochemical immunosensing of CEA.

sections.heading: 2.1.1.1. Silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs)
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles, one of the strongest conductive nanomaterials, have attracted great attention due to their quantum characteristics of small granule diameter and large specific surface area as well as their ability to quickly transfer photoinduced electrons at the surfaces of colloidal particles [18, 19]. The immobilized silver nanoparticles on the hollow polyelectrolyte increased the conjugated amount of biomolecules, and strengthened the electron transfer. Chen et al. [20] prepared a novel redox-active magnetic nanocomposite for improvement of electrochemical properties by using poly(o-phenylenediamine) as cross-linkage layer between magnetic nanoparticles and silver nanoparticles. The assay was based on a sandwich-type

immunoassay protocol by using nanogold-patterned graphene oxide nanoscales (AuNP-GO), conjugated with horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-CEA, as secondary antibodies and biofunctionalized magnetic nanostructures as immunosensing probes (Scheme 1). According to Chen and coworkers report, LOD is 1.0 pg mL-1.

sections.heading: 2.1.1.2. Gold nanoparticles (Au NPs)
sections.text: Among metal nanoparticles, AuNPs have been widely used in bio-sensing in biological media. This tendency to AuNPs is related to their fascinatingly physical properties including optical, electro-chemical, catalytic and electromagnetic properties, stability and biological compatibility. In addition, morphology and size dispersion of AuNPs are controllable and easy to improve surface properties. In AuNPs assisted bioassay, the plasmon resonance frequency changes because of coupling of the electric fields between particles [21]. Song and coworkers [22] prepared a novel pH-dependent electrochemical immunosensor by using bovine serum albumin (BSA)-Ab1/chitosan (CHIT)-AuNPs/three-dimensional kenaf stem-derived macroporous carbon (3D-KSCs) integrated electrode as the signal collector and AuNPs-Ab2-glucose oxidase (GOx)-ConA as a tracing tag for the CEA detection.In this report, The CEA was assayed by using the AuNPs-Ab2-GOD-ConA as tracing tag and the BSA-Ab1/CHIT-AuNPs/3D-KSCs integrated electrode as signal collector based on a sandwich-type mode. Finally, the impedance signal of immunosensor (CEA/BSA-Ab1/CHITAuNPs/3D-KSCs) was recorded. According to this report, the dynamic range was 0.004 to 50 ng. mL-1 for the detection of CEA using prepared immunosensor. Also, the detection limit was estimated to be 1.3 pg.mL-1. Han et al, [23] reported a sandwich-type non-enzymatic electrochemical immunosensor for detection of CEA. In this report, Au NPs were introduced to link substrate materials and primary antibodies (Ab1) and accelerate the electron transfer in this system. At the same time, the palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs-vanadium pentoxide (V2O5)/multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were used as the label of secondary antibodies (Ab2). Scheme 2 explains the fabrication procedure of the electrochemical immunosensor. The prepared immunosensor showed wide linear range from 0.5 pg. mL-1 to 25 ng.mL-1 with limit of detection of 0.17 pg.mL-1. Interestingly, a novel label-free electrochemical immunosensor was designed by Yang and coworkers [24] for detecting CEA based on three-dimensional (3D) gold nanoparticles/prussian blue (PB)-poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (AuNPs/PB-PEDOT) nanocomposite. The 3D nanocomposite not only possessed large surface area and favorable microenvironment, but also exhibited remarkable conductivity, stability and excellent biocompatibility. In addition, PB showed excellent redox properties. Then AuNPs/PBPEDOT was used as both electron mediators and 3D matrices in the fabrication of immunosensor (see scheme 3 for deteiless). According to this report, the AuNPs/PB-PEDOT modified immunosensor showed dynamic range 0.05 to 40 ng.mL-1, while the detection limit was 0.01 ng.mL-1 for CEA.

sections.heading: 2.1.1.3. Metal oxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
Metal oxide nanomaterial has unique optical and electrical properties, high catalytic efficiency with desired functionalities and surface charge properties, which provides remarkable platforms for interfacing biorecognition elements with sensor for signal amplification [25]. Recently, a novel electrochemical immunosensor for determination of CEA in human serum was fabricated by depositing Mo-Mn3O4/MWCNTs/Chits nanocomposite onto an indium-tin oxide (ITO) electrode [26]. Mo-doped Mn3O4 (MMO) was synthesized by sol-gel method and the presence of molybdenum improved its electrochemical properties. The MMO/ MWCNTs/Chits nanocomposite can can accelerate the electron

transfer rate and enlarge the surface area to capture a large number of CEA. The electrochemical immunosensor can detect CEA in a linear range from 0.1 ng.mL-1 to 125 ng.mL-1 with a detection limit of 4.9 pg.mL-1. Therefore, cuprous oxide nanowires (Cu2O NWs) with good electronic features and good electrocatalytic performance become a kind of promising nanomaterials. A sandwich-type electrochemical immunosensor was fabricated for the quantitative detection CEA based on using the Ag@Cu2O nanocomposites as the labels to conjugate with the secondary antibodies (Ab2) (See Scheme 5 for detailes) [27]. Due to the special electrochemical performance of Ag@Cu2O nanocomposites, the immunosensor exhibited high sensitivity and low detection limit of 0.18 fg.mL-1.

sections.heading: 2.1.1.4. Bi- and Trimetallic nanoparticles
sections.text: Interestingly, an ultrasensitive sandwich-type electrochemical immunosensor was designed by Thian et al. [28] for the detection of CEA. This immunosensor was prepared by using the trimetallic NiAuPt nanoparticles on graphene nanosheets (NGs) nanosheets (NiAuPt-NGs) as excellent labels and β-cyclodextrin functionalized reduced graphene oxide nanosheets (CDNGs) as the platform. The CD-NGs with high specific surface area good biocompatibility and the ideal dispersibility was used to capture the primary antibodies (Ab1) efficiently (See scheme 6 for details). The trimetallic NiAuPt-NGs nanocomposites were used as the labels for signal amplification, showing better electrocatalytic activity towards the reduction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which is much better than that the monometallic Pt-NGs, bimetallic NiPt-NGs and AuPt-NGs due to the synergetic effect presented in NiAuPt-NGs. The NiAuPt-NGs nanocomposites consist of tightly coupled nanostructures of Au, Ni and Pt, which have neither an alloy nor a core-shell structure. Based on this report, a linear range from 0.001-100 ng.mL-1 and a low detection limit of 0.27 pg.mL-1 were obtained for CEA. Also, a novel label-free immunosensor for detection of CEA based on Pd-Ir bimetallic nanoparticles as a catalyst was prepared by Zheng et al., [29]. In this report, CEA antibody (anti-CEA) was immobilized onto the surface of glassy carbon electrode through the adsorption effect of Pd-Ir bimetallic nanoparticles modified on the electrode using chitosan. When CEA antibody combines with CEA antigen, the formed immunocomplexs blocks the catalytic activity of Pd-Ir bimetal nanoparticles to the reduction of H2O2, leading to decrease in the current response signal. The decrease of the current response of the immunosensor has a linear relationship with the concentration of CEA ranging from 0.05 to 50 ng.mL-1 with a detection limit of 0.017 ng.mL-1. The sensor provides a new simple method for the determination of CEA.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Hyperbranched polymers
sections.text:
Hyperbranched polymers have attracted significant attention for their unique architecture and novel properties including good solubility, special viscosity behavior, and high density of initiating groups that can initiate polymerization of different kinds of monomers. Owing to the unique architecture of hyperbranched polymers, the multifunctional groups' properties can be utilized to construct biosensor by the chemical modification of the terminal-groups. Acknowledging the benefits of hyperbranched polymers, Miao et al. [30] report the design and synthesis of a new kind of immunosensor for detection CEA. In this report, the hyperbranched polyester was grafted to the surface of indium tin oxides glass (ITO) electrode. Then, CEA and horse radish peroxidase (HRP)-labeled antibodyconjugated AuNPs

(HRP-Ab2-AuNPs) bioconjugates were immobilized on the surface of the hyperbranched structure-modified electrode. Moreover, the analytical performance of the prepared immunosensor showed a high sensitivity, a linear range from 0.01 to 80 ng. mL-1 with a low detection limit of 2.36 pg mL-1. Interestingly, hyperbranched polyester nanoparticles with carboxylic acid functional groups (HBPE-CA NPs) were synthesized and combined with chitosan wrapped around Au nanoparticles (CS-Au NPs) to prepare a novel and sensitive electrochemical immunosensor by adsorption of anti-CEA on the (HBPE-CA)/CS-Au NPs modified glass carbon electrode (GCE) [31]. The prepared immunosensor by Sun and coworkers (Scheme 7) displayed a good amperometric response to CEA. Moreover, based on the antibiofouling properties, this immunosensor can is able to the direct detection of CEA in whole blood, and exhibited a wide detection range (1-107 fg. mL-1), and a low detection limit of 0.251 fg. mL-1. From this report it's found that, the described immunosensor by these researchers can provide a promising immunoassay strategy for clinical applications, since the values we measured in whole blood directly are likely closer to the real values. Also, a new electrochemical immunosensor based on poly(o-phenylenediamine) nanospheres was prepared for the rapid detection of CEA via the inhibition of enzymatic activity [32]. In this report, poly(o-phenylenediamine) nanospheres were utilized as the support for immobilizing horseradish peroxidase-labeled polyclonal rabbit anti-human CEA antibody (HRP-anti-CEA) on a pretreated glassy carbon electrode (GCE) using glutaraldehyde as a crosslinker. Based on this report, in the presence of target CEA, an antigen-antibody immunocomplex formed on the electrode. This results in a partial inhibition of the active center of HRP and decreases the activity of HRP in terms of H2O2 reduction. According to this report, the LOD was 3.2 pg. mL-1.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Graphene and its derivatives
sections.text:
Two dimential graphene, sp2- hybridized carbon, has emerged recently as a nanoscale material with high surface area and other important properties including excellent electrical conductivity and a small band gap. Electronic properties of graphene have been discussed widely in the literature [33] and will not be addressed here.
This material can be used to modify the surface of a microtiter plate (MTP) or a sensing chip/electrode to accommodate very high biomolecule loadings to improve detection sensitivity and other bioanalytical parameters. Graphene-based electrodes exhibit superior electrocatalysis over carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [34] and significantly lower charge-transfer resistance compared to graphite and glassy carbon (GC) materials [35]. This section of review aims to unravel the role, current pending technical issues and future feasibility of this fascinating graphene based nanomaterial in various detection schemes for CEA.
Du and Liu et al., have done some pioneered work on graphene based electrochemical immunosensors [34, 35]. They reported the graphene modified electrode for enhanced detection of biomarkers [34]. In another paper [35], they reported a new electrochemical immunosensor based on graphene oxide for detection of a protein biomarker, phosphorylated p53. GO was used as a nanocarrier for immobilization of multiple enzyme molecules, which was used as immunoassay labels for signal amplification. A similar approach using thionine and functionalized GO has been reported for enhanced sensitivity for detection of CEA (Schem 8) [36]. Alternatively, after binding to the cAb-CEA complex, the labeled HRP will be close contact with the electrode surface to catalyze H2O2 reduction and this approach has

been frequently used in Electrochemical (EC) immunoassay. Without the enzyme, the graphene electrode does not exhibit high electrocatalysis for H2O2 reduction. Recently, Samanman et al. [37] proposed a simple method for the immobilization of antibody on the cryogel surface was employed by incorporating gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) in the CSGP nanocomposite where the antibody can directly chemisorp on the AuNPs surface via the NH2- group [38]. The formed antigen-antibody immunocomplex on the electrode surface would hinder the electron transfer, and thus, reduce the oxidation peak current response that can be correlated to the antigen concentration. The LOD was 2.0 × 10-7 ng. mL-1.
Peng, et al [39] reported a sandwich type electrochemical immunosensor for sensitive detection of CEA based on a signal amplification mechanism (without using DNA or enzyme) resulting from Fe3O4/Au NPs and graphene/chitosan-ferrocen as the sensor platform. In this work, the sensitive determination of CEA is achieved by catalytic reduction of p-nitrophenol to electroactive p-aminophenol (AP) using gold-nanocatalyst labels (See Scheme 10 for detailes). The prepared immunosensor by these researchers offered a sensitive determination of CEA in the range of 0.001-30 ng. mL-1 with a detection limit of 0.39 pg. mL-1.
Huang et al. reported an approach toward development of advanced immunosensors based on chemically functionalized Ag/Au nanoparticles coated on graphene for the detection of CEA in clinical immunoassay [40]. The prepared method by Huang and coworkers (Scheme 11) can respond to CEA with a linear calibration range from 10 to 1.2 pg. mL-1 with a detection limit of 8 pg. mL-1. Graphene, sp2-hybridized carbon, and its two major derivatives, graphene oxide (GO) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) have played an important role in immunoassay (IAs) and immunosensing (IMS) platforms for the detection of CEA, an implicated tumor biomarker found in several types of cancer. The graphene family with high surface area is functionalized to form stable nanocomposites with gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) and electron mediators. The capture anti-CEA antibody (Ab) with high density can be anchored on AuNPs of such composites to provide remarkable detection sensitivity, significantly below the level found in normal subjects and cancer patients. Electrochemical properties of graphene-based nanocomposites are exploited in various detection schemes. Future endeavors are envisioned for the development of an array platform with high-throughput for CEA together with other tumor biomarkers and C-reactive protein, a universal biomarker for infection and inflammation. The ongoing efforts dedicated to the replacement of a lab-based detector by a cellphone with smart applications will further enable cost-effective and frequent monitoring of CEA in order to establish its clinical relevance and provide tools for real-time monitoring of patients during chemotherapy.

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Other nanomaterials
sections.text:
Apart from the above-discussed immunosensors, other types of nanomaterial based CEA electrochemical immunosensors have been reported in the literature. In this subsection, we briefly discuss some of these immunosensors. Zhao and coworkers [41] develop lectin-based immunosensor array with different lectins as molecular recognition elements to detect the content and the aberrant glycosylation of CEA with high specificity and high-throughout. Also, Park et al [42] describe fabrication of a Field-effect transistors (FETs)-type aptamer sensor to detect CEA based on the carboxylated polypyrrole multidimensional nanotubes (C-PPy MNTs) conjugated with a CEA-binding
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
10
aptamer. Scheme 13 illustrates the overall procedure for fabrication of C-PPy MNTs. The detection limit was approximately 1 fg.mL-1. A novel sandwich-type electrochemical immunosensors for detection of CEA by using GOAuNPs as the platform and Fe3O4@SiO2-Fc-Ab2/HRP as the signal amplification probe was designed by Feng and coworkers [43]. In this work, the Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2 surface was used as linked reagents for co-immobilization of ferrocenecarboxylic acid (Fc-COOH) and secondary anti-CEA (Ab2) to prepare the signal probe, and it also can hasten the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to amplify signals (See scheme 14 A&B for details). The designed immunosensor shows an excellent analytical performance wide dynamic response range of CEA concentration from 0.001 ng.mL-1 to 80 ng.mL-1 with a relatively low detection limit of 0.0002 ng.mL-1. From this report, it is found that, the main advantages and significance of the immunosensor contribute to several aspects: (i) using GOAuNPs as the platforms can enhance the immobilization of Ab1 to capture the released signal amplification probe and accelerate electron transfer from Fc-COOH to the electrode surfaces. (ii) the Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2 has abundant binding sites for loading a large amount of FcCOOH, and can speed the decomposition of H2O2 with amplified signals. (iii) the HRP also can accelerate the decomposition of H2O2. Thus, the strategy provides a general consideration for the design of sensor in the detection of other biomarkers. Interestingly, researchers from Stony Brook University [44] prepared a quantitative real-time detection method for CEA from pancreatic cyst fluid using 3-D surface molecular imprinting. In this report, CEA was templated on gold surface (RMS roughness ∼3-4 nm) coated with a hydrophilic selfassembled monolayer (SAM) on the working electrode of an open circuit potentiometric network. The subsequent removal of template CEA makes the immunosensor capable of CEA detection based on its specific structure and conformation. The molecular imprinting (MI) immunosensor was further calibrated using the potentiometric responses in solutions with known CEA concentrations and a detection limit of 0.5 ng.ml-1 was achieved. Also, a sandwich-type electrochemical immunosensor for detection CEA was fabricated based on supermolecular labeling strategy [45]. In this work, β-cyclodextrin (β-CD)-based host-guest recognition was used to immobilize capture antibody and label detection antibody. According to this report, β-CDs functionalized multiwalled carbon nanotube (CDs-MWCNT) was used to immobilize adamantanecarboxylic acid (ADA) functionalized capture antibody onto electrode surface based on host-guest interaction between ADA and β-CD. The detection antibody was first labeled with ferrocenecarboxylic acid (Fc) and then attached to magnetic Fe3O4@SiO2 core-shell nanoparticles based on the inclusion interaction between Fc and β-CD. Fc acts as not only a linker molecule but also electroactive specie. The multiplex labeling of Fc on Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles enabled the signals amplification for CEA after the specific immunoreaction, which was monitored by square wave voltammetry. The immunosensor described by Yan and coworkers displayed a suitable linear range from 0.001 ng.mL-1 to 15 ng.mL-1 with a detection limit of 0.33 pg.mL-1 for CEA. From the evaluation of the literature surveyed and, irrespective of the particularities of each type of immunoassay, the utility of nanomaterials (nanoparticles or nanostructures) in the different constructional stages and operating roles of the final immunodevices can be summarized as follows: i) electrochemical catalysts to enhance the signal produced by the reporting reaction, ii) electron wires to facilitate direct electron communication processes, iii) carriers of enzyme labels, iv) electrochemical labels, v) immobilization platforms to allow high loadings of key components etc. These functions, not offered by bulk materials, are highly desirable and have conclusively contributed to stimulating developments in immunoassay.

Despite the researches done at the academic level and the significant achievements reached in the design and development of highly sensitive and selective electrochemical immunosensors based on enzyme, metal nanoparticles or QDs labelling, these developments are not reflected in the availability of widely used commercial products. Among the reasons why electrochemical immunosensors are not sufficiently represented in the market are: i) the lack of sufficient internal validation studies for the intended purpose describing the method procedure, general requirements, the applicability and the basic performance characteristics such as precision, trueness and selectivity, ii) the lack of extended comparison studies with well-established techniques, iii) the lack of effective solutions to address fundamental analytical issues associated with non-specific binding, the stability/reproducibility of the measurements, the long-term stability of the developed devices etc., and iv) the relatively high cost of nanomaterials as well as the lengthy and sometimes complicated protocols used to developed immunosensors incorporating nanomaterials. We believe that coordinated efforts to address these issues are expected to provide a considerable impetus so that electrochemical immunosensors can attain a competitive position in the global immunodiagnostics market. 2.2. Electrochemiluminescence (ECL) based immunosensing of EA Electrochemiluminescence (ECL), the generation of an optical signal triggered by an electrochemical reaction, has the inherent advantages of versatility, sensitivity, selectivity, simplified optical setup, good temporal and spatial control, and wide linear range for clinical tests and biomolecules detection [46]. Solid-state ECL, viz. immobilizing the ECL substrate on the electrode surface, can reduce the consumption of expensive reagent, enhance the ECL signal, simplify experimental design and create regenerable sensors. Therefore, solid-state ECL system is more suitable for biomolecular sensing [47, 48]. The electrochemiluminescence (ECL) is hyphenated method of analysis in which the electrochemical and luminescent techniques are combining together; consequently, the electrochemically excited photon was amplified and quantified with a photomultiplier (PMT) [49]. ECL is another new trend in particle-based immunoassay. An ECL label is tagged to NP bioconjugates, which are immobilized on the electrode surface. The most popular ECL label, tris(2,20-bipyridyl)ruthenium(II), ([Ru(bpy)3]
2+), emits light when it reacts with ions, enzymes, tripropylamine (TPrA), etc. The reductant is oxidized at the electrode surface, which reacts with [Ru(bpy)3] 2+ to yield [Ru(bpy)3] 3+, which is measured by a photomultiplier, a charge-coupled device, etc. Together with ECL, this technology will find its widespread application to monitor the trace level of CEA. In this sub-section, we comprehensively summarize the selected latest research articles on application of various ECL based immunosensors for quantitive detection of CEA. Also, we comprehensively summarize the selected latest research articles on application of various nanomaterial based ECL immunosensors for detection of CEA. In general, the review breaks into three parts. The first part devotes to the development and applications of nanoparticles in single or multi-analyte analyte ECL immunosensors for CEA. The second part provides an overview of the application of nanoparticles combined with carbon based nanomaterials towards ECL based immunosensing of CEA 2.2.1. Nanoparticles Among all the ECL systems, tris (bipyridine)-ruthenium (II) ([Ru(bpy)3]2) has been widely used in ECL analysis because of its superior properties, including high sensitivity and good stability under moderate conditions in aqueous solution [50].

By incorporation with nanoparticles (NPs), the formations of NPs/biomolecule conjugation and NPs amplifying label platform enhance the signal, and provide the basis for ultrasensitive immunoassay [51]. For immobilizing biomolecules, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have been recognized as a versatile and efficient platform for the conjugation of biomolecules for their good electroconductibility, large specific surface area and versatility in surface modification [52]. For signal amplification, luminol functionalized gold nanoparticles (Lu-AuNPs) have been used as ideal material for labeling, which not only retain the high efficiency ECL property of luminol, but also own the good stability and simple coupling procedure to antibody or antigen of AuNPs[53]. Li and coworkers [54] prepared an ECL based immunosensor for the detection of CEA on a portable indium tin oxide device. In this report, the gold nanoparticle-coated silica nanosphere aggregated with Ru(bpy)3
2+ was used as a label with the signal amplification technique. Also, the amino-functionalized Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were treated with 3- (2-aminoethylamino)propyltrimethoxysilane. The primary monoclonal antibody to CEA antigen was immobilized onto the surface of Fe3O4 by glutaraldehyde as coupling agent (See scheme 15 for details). According to this report, the concentrations of CEA were obtained in the linear range of 0.001-10 ng/ml with a detection limit of 0.3 pg/ml. 2.2.2. Nanoparticles combined with carbon based nanomaterials Composites of GO and MWCNTs with nanoparticles were adopted as large matrix for loading luminescent or catalytic material [55]. Due to π-π restacking of GO, the electrochemical properties of the GO were limited. Based on this phenomenon, Pang and coworkers [56] used nanocomposites of graphene oxide/carboxylated multiwall carbon nanotubes/gold/cerium oxide nanoparticles (GO/MWCNTs-COOH/Au@CeO2) as CEA antibody carriers and describe a new platform for immunosensing of CEA based on ECL method. In this report, CeO2 nanoparticles were firstly exploited as an ECL luminescent material and GO/MWCNTs-COOH was used as a loading matrix for CeO2 nanoparticles because of the superior conductivity and large specific surface area (See scheme 16 for details). The proposed immunosensor showed the broad linear range (0.05~100 ng/mL) and the low detection limit (LOD, 0.02 ng/mL). 2.2.3. Upconversion nanoparticles According to benefits of upconversion nanoparticles comminuted with graphene, a novel ECL immunosensor for detection of CEA based on the reduced graphene Oxide-BaYF5:Yb, Er (rGO-BaYF5:Yb, Er) nanocomposites was proposed by Zhao and coworkers [57]. In this report, The rGO-BaYF5:Yb, Er nanocomposites, used as electrode luminescence materials. Further, poly (diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA), Au nanoparticles (AuNPs), and Anti-CEA were successively assembled on the surface of rGO-BaYF5:Yb, Er nanocomposites modified-electrode for fabricating ECL immunosensor (see scheme 17 for details). This novel ECL immunosensor exhibited high sensitive response to CEA in a linear range of 0.001-80 ng mL1 with a low detection limit of 0.87 pg mL-1. From the discussed examples, it is found that although the application of UCNPs in the immunosensing of CEA was investigated but the fabrication of UCNPs is very complicated and it requires using strict reaction condition, long reaction time and high reaction temperature. Moreover, the leaching of UCNPs can be released the toxic heavy metals into the surroundings. 2.2.4. Quantum dots On the application of quantum dots for detection of CEA, interestingly, a ratiometric electrochemiluminescence (ECL) immunosensing approach based on two different ECL emitters: CdS quantum dots (QDs) as cathodic emitter and luminol as anodic emitter was proposed by Huang et al., [58]. The ECL immunosensor was constructed by a layer-by-layer

modification of CdS QDs, Au nanoparticles and capture antibody on a GCE. Upon the formation of sandwich immunoassay, the lumiol/palladium nanoclusters (Pd NCs)@graphene oxide probe was introduced to the electrode (see scheme 18 for detailes). This ratiometric ECL strategy were used for immunosensing of CEA with a linear range of 1.0- 100 pg/mL and a detection limit of 0.62 pg/mL. |From this work, it's found that, the probe not only highly loaded the Pd NCs and luminol to enhance the anode ECL of luminol but also competitively consumed the H2O2 coreactant to decline the cathode ECL of CdS QDs. Thus, the ratio ECL intensity between luminol and CdS QDs can be significantly enhanced at the proposed immunosensor via electrocatalysis of co-reactant H2O2.The enhanced ratiometric ECL signal resulted from the high density and excellent electrocatalysis of the loaded Pd NCs. More recently, Zhang and colleagues [59] designed a new electrochemiluminescence (ECL) immunosensor for detection of CEA by utilizing multifunctionalized flower-like Au@BSA nanoparticles as biosensing interface. Based on this report, dynamic range was from 0.001 to 200 ng/mL with a low detection limit of 0.0003 ng/mL. Quantum clusters are a new class of luminescent materials with only a few atoms in the core, attracting enormous attention due to their optical and electronic properties. Based on good opto-electrical properties of Quantum clusters, China researchers [60] prepared bovine serum albumin protected gold nanoclusters (AuNCs@BSA) and applied as illuminant in the ELC detection of CEA. For enhanced the ECL signal intensity of AuNCs@BSA, a novel nanoporous NP-NiGd-Ni2O3-Gd2O3 alloy was prepared for ECL immunosensor fabrication. Based on this report, the ECL immunosensor exhibited a wide range from 0.0001 to 5 ng/mL with a detection limit of 0.03 pg/mL. The above described immunosensor demonstrate the broad potential of bio-conjugated GQDs for amplified transduction of bio-molecular recognition events. Given the optical and electrochemical applications, GQDs labels provide the basis for ultrasensitive assays of CEA. The remarkable sensitivity of the new GQDs-based sensing protocols opens up the possibility for detecting CEA. Such highly sensitive bio-detection schemes could provide early detection of diseases or a warning of a terrorist attack. The use of GQDs for detecting CEA is still in its infancy, but the lessons learned in ultrasensitive CEA detection should provide useful starting points. The successful realization of the new signal-amplification strategies requires proper attention to nonspecific adsorption issues that commonly control the detectability of bioaffinity assays. Proper washing and surface blocking steps should thus be employed to avoid amplification of background signals (associated with non-specific adsorption of the GQDs). Due to the minority of research being on development new GQDs-based immunosensors, more techniques should be involved in this area. With GQDs, it will be possible for immunosensors to be applied to pre-warning and real-time detection of CEA [61]. In this case, we have discussed the promising future of incorporating GQDs into the field of immunosensing, specifically their current roles in detection of CEA. The advantages of GQDs on immunosensing and enhancement of signal were compared with other reports, together with their analytical application on biological systems. But, there are many challenges ahead that must be addressed before GQDs can be successfully integrated into immunodevice. The main advances required, in our opinions, include the following.
(i) Advanced techniques and facile methods are needed to increase the sensitivity of GQDs-based immunosensors towards signal amplification and highly sensitive detection of CEA. (ii) Further research is required into various functionalized GQDs to promote cell adhesion, sensitivity, selectivity, and so on which is necessary for immunosensing.

(iii)More specialized coatings to minimize nonspecific bonding are needed for CEA immunosensing. (iv) Protocols and further experiments should be conducted to determine the exact nature of the nano-toxicity of GQDs. (v) Innovative solutions are required to reduce fabrication and running costs of GQDs micro- and nano-fluidic devices to make them economically viable for detection of CEA in real samples and cell lines. (vi) Results raise doubts about the repeatability, reproducibility, and comparability of GQD- based immunosensors, as, with every emerging technology, standards need to be established to avoid the doubts about the lack of reproducibility, repeatability, and compatibility across platforms and laboratories. (vii) Finally, we conclude that there is a bright opportunity for further advances and developments of immunosensors based on functionalized GQDs, especially through further miniaturization and integration into lab-on-chip systems. The design of implantable devices with the ability to monitor CEA in vivo and in real time is promising for the application of immunosensors, even though it is yet to be explored. Scientists therefore have a great deal to do to address the performance of immunosensors for CEA detection in the future. In conclusion of this sub-section, it is worthwhile to note that photoelectrochemical-based detection is another high-sensitive quantification method for sensing of CEA. However, its application relies on an expensive and sophisticated fluorometer. In addition, its sensitivity suffers from the auto-fluorescence of paper and laminating materials and the opacity nature of paper. Thus, its in-field POC use is somewhat limited, especially in poorly developed areas. In contrast, it is reasonable to expect that more test strip products and their portable EC detectors like home-testing glucometers will be brought to the market.

sections.heading: 2.3. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) immunosensing of CEA
sections.text:
Recently, with the development POCT devices, more and more attention has been put to integrate the photoelectrochemical (PEC) sensor into POCT devices. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) immunoassay is a newly developed analyticalmethod that is expected to have the advantages of both fluorescence and electrochemical sensors [62]. As a promising analytical method for the detection of biomolecules, photoelectrochemical immunosensing possesses the advantages of high selectivity and sensitivity because of the separation of the excitation source and the detection signal [63]. In addition, electronic detection instruments are simple, low-cost, and well-suited for rapid and high-throughput biological assays. Thus, this technique shows promising analytical applications and has attracted considerable research interest. Signal amplification is the most popular strategy that has been extensively used for the development of highly sensitive PEC immunoassay method. The use of nanomaterials as signal amplifiers is of particular interest in biosensor design, due to their outstanding electronic and biocompatible performance. In this section, we comprehensively summarize the selected latest research articles on application of various nanomaterial based PEC immunosensors for detection of CEA. In general, the review breaks into three parts. The first part devotes to the development and applications of nanoparticles in single or multi-analyte analyte photoelectrochemical immunosensors for CEA. The second part provides an overview of the recent graphene-based photoelectrochemical immunosensors for detection of CEA.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Nanoparticles
sections.text: Owing to simple and portable instrument, high sensitivity, fast response, and low fabrication cost, photoelectrochemical (PEC) sensor, have attracted more and more attention in a wide range of areas, including clinical diagnosis, biological research and bio-logical biodefense applications. To develop high-performance, sensitive-enhanced and portable PEC sensors, attention should be focused on innovative approaches that couple highly efficient PEC materials and excellent substrates [64]. Great efforts are currently focusing on the development of effective signal amplification strategies fo achieving highly sensitive immunoassay/immunosensors using the photoelectrochemical method [65]. Recently, titanium dioxide is one of the most commonly employed materials because of its nontoxicity, low-cost and brilliant photochemical and chemical stability. Nevertheless, due to a wide energy band gap of 3.0 eV, TiO2 can only absorb the ultraviolet light (<387 nm) [6]. So applications of pure TiO2 are also limited. Another class of photoactive materials is metalfree polymeric semiconductor. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), a moderate energy bandgap of 2.7 eV, has paid more and more attentions because it is very stable in acid or alkaline electrolytes [67]. However, applications of pure g-C3N4 are also limited largely because of its low quantum efficiency and high electron-hole recombination rate. As mentioned above, researchers have therefore made great efforts to expand the application of pure TiO2 and pure g-C3N4 by various methods, such as coupling it with other materials, nanostructuring and doping [68]. Thus, owing to the proper band level between g-C3N4 and TiO2, g-C3N4 and TiO2 are combined together leading to the easy separation of the photo-generated electron and hole. Although there are some references about the combination of g-C3N4 and TiO2, the morphology of TiO2 is mainly focused on nanorod [69], nanoparticles and nanotube [70]. Based on this description, Wang and coworkers [71] prepared a PEC immunosensor for detection and determination of CEA based on 2D TiO2 nanosheets and carboxylated graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4). In this report, carboxylated g-C3N4 was attached to 2D TiO2 nanosheets through the bond formed between carboxyl group of carboxylated g-C3N4 and TiO2 (See scheme 20 for details). Then, antibody of CEA was bonded to TiO2 through the dentate bond formed between carboxyl group of anti-CEA and TiO2, leading to the decrease of the photocurrents. Based on this report and under the optimal conditions, the intensity decreased linearly with CEA concentration in the range of 0.01~10 ng/mL. The detection limit is 2.1 pg/mL.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Quantum dots
sections.text:
As one kind of semiconductor nanocrystals, water soluble CdSe quantum dots (QDs) with unique size-dependent properties have been paid more and more attentions in the field of photoelectrochemical bioassay [72]. Recently, for enhancing effective photoelectric activity area of CdSe QDs, Li and coworkers [73] proposed using the melamine, a star-shaped triamino molecule, for readily capturing CdSe QDs and forming a CdSe/melamine network through strong interactions between the carboxyl groups of CdSe QDs and the three amino groups of each melamine molecule. Due to this amplification of photoelectrochemical signals and the special structure of the label (Scheme 21), the fabricated photoelectrochemical immunosensor was applied for detection of CEA, and displayed a wide linear range (0.005- 1000 ng/mL) and low detection limit (5 pg/mL). Discussed articles indicated that, CEA have been successfully detected by current designs (photoelectrochemical) with high sensitivity and specificity; however, often more than one biomarker is required to accurately predict cancer, therefore multiplex detection is urgently needed for current clinical diagnostics. In fact, many studies areworking on this area and multiplex detection has been one of the main focuses of current paper-based devices.

Multiplex detection has many advantages: it is very convenient to detect several types of analytes on a single device simultaneously, which can save a lot of time, space and cost; analyzing several biomolecules that are related to each other will give a more comprehensive understanding of a disease. Furthermore, all sorts of information can be collected and stored in the same systemand exported through a barcode, and patient can read the results quickly and efficiently by scanning it using a smartphone. Nevertheless, few commercialized applications refer to multiplex detection due to limitations, such as: potential interactions between multiple different antibodies and antigens in the sample/assay solution; certain proteins in biological samples may affect multiplex results and so on. At the same time, multiplex detection requires incorporating similar or completely different working mechanisms together, which is a high demand for platformdesign and fabrication. Therefore, more and more fascinating techniques should be developed for further investigation. 2.4. Optical immunosensors Various spectroscopic methods have been used on the analysis of cancer biomarkers. These methods have both advantages and disadvantages. For example, fluorescence based methods are very sensitive to very low concentrations of analyte; also absorption methods are very simple. Recently, near-infrared fluorescence (NIRF) imaging techniques have brought high attentions in non-invasive assessments with high sensitivity and specificity. The use of emission on low frequency region (650-900 nm) is of great importance because it provides a non-invasive detection. Due to less tissue auto fluorescence, light absorption and penetration of near infrared (NIR) across of tissues, the NIR is extremely used in biomedical recognitions [74]. This sub-section of review aims to explore progress to date various features of materials for optical immunosensingimmunosensing of CEA. Moreover, as another aim of this section is to provide insight into the intensity based spectroscopic methods which are applied in CEA immunosensing discussing their advantages and disadvantages. More importantly, we discuss in detail different aspects of the applied optical immunosensors (e.g., formation, detection techniques, labels and sensitivity). Consequently, we discuss several outstanding properties of the optical methods, research opportunities and the development potential and prospects. 2.4.1. Nanoparticles (NPs) AuNPs have been widely used in optical immunosensing [75]. Based on fascinatingly physical, chemical and electrical properties of Au NPs high, a novel method for real-time detection of CEA was repoerted by Li and colleagues [76]. In this report, Au NPs modified with streptavidin (SA) were used to the determination of CEA in the 1-60 ng.mL-1 concentration range with a 1 ng.mL-1 detection limit using SPR method. Interestingly, Zhang and coworkers [77] prepared a miniaturized platform based on a Love Wave immunosensor (Ab loaded on Au NP modified by LiTaO3) that can achieve automatic biochemical reactions and real-time measurement of CEA in exhaled breath condensate with the limit of detection of 1.25 ng. mL-1. Also, a flow injection chemiluminescence (CL) assay for CEA detection based on sandwich system of CEA/anti-CEA/goat-anti-mouse IgG functionalized AuNPs was reported by Hao and Ma [78]. The CL intensity of the system was linearly related to the logarithm of CEA concentration in the range of 100 pg. mL-1 to 1,000 ng. mL-1, with a detection limit of 20 pg. mL-1. Acoustic sensors such as surface acoustic wave (SAW) and film bulk acoustic resonator (FBAR) have been used for biosensing applications in the last decade due to their higher resonant frequency, greater sensitivity, lower cost, and smaller size than comparable quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) sensors [79]. Furthermore, AlN-based FBAR sensors offer promise in other applications because of their compatibility with monolithic microwave

integrated circuits [80]. Over the past few years, remarkable results have been reported in the applications of FBAR for liquid sensing, gas sensing, and biological detection [81]. But there are few reports concerning label-free detection of CEA with an aptamer modified FBAR biosensor. CEA is one of the most widely used tumor markers in the clinical diagnosis of breast, colorectal, and lung cancer making monitoring of CEA very important for clinical tumor diagnoses [82].

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Upconverting nanoparticles (UCNPs)
sections.text:
Recently, upconverting nanoparticles were used in development of a new sandwich-type immunoassay for the quantification of CEA using fluorescence spectroscopy [83]. In this report, CEA amine-functionalized Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) were conjugated with capture anti-CEA antibodies and amine-functionalized NaY0.78F4:Yb0.20, Ho0.02 upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) were conjugated with detection anti-CEA antibodies, respectively (see scheme 22 for details). Based on a sandwich-type immunoassay format, the detection limit for CEA was 2.5 pg. mL-1, and the linear range of CEA detection was from 0.1 ng. mL-1 to 2.5 pg. mL-1. Also, Wu et al. [84] reported an aptasensor for CEA determination using upconversion phosphors (UCPs) and carbon nanoparticles (CNPs) on the basis of fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET). Using this optical immunosensor, CEA was detect in the concentration rang of 0.1-40 ng. mL-1 in human serum samples. From the discussed examples, it is found that although the application of UCNPs in the intensity based optical immunosensing of CEA and ions but the fabrication of UCNPs is very complicated and it requires using strict reaction condition, long reaction time and high reaction temperature. Moreover, the leaching of UCNPs can be released the toxic heavy metals into the surroundings. 2.4.3. Graphene and its derivatives A label-free technique based on surface plasmon resonance (SPR) also deserves a brief mention considering some recent developments in SPR biosensing with graphene modified sensing gold chips. A graphene sheet can be used to coat an Au SPR chip to increase the adsorption of biomolecules [85]. GO can self-assemble on an SPR Au surface modified by 1- octadecanethiol to provide remarkable detection sensitivity for bovine serum albumin, down to 100 of pg. mL-1 compared to 10 µg. mL-1 for conventional SPR, i.e., about 100-fold more sensitive [86].
3. Conclusion Many different analytical methods for determination of CEA such as electrochemical, fluorometric analysis, photoelectrochemical immunoassay and chemiluminescence immunoassay provide a sensitive and specific technique were discused. But generally require multiple steps and time-consuming procedures such as labeling and sample treatment prior to detection. However, these labeling methods are not suitable in some cases, because labeling materials may occupy the important binding sites or cause steric hindrance, resulting in false information. Above discussed articles show that, SPR is powerful analytical techniques for direct monitoring of CEA, without the need for intrinsic or extrinsic labeling to the target molecules. Therefore, CEA immunosensors based on SPR is a suitable method for sensitivity, reliability, reproducibilitic sensing of CEA.

Most applications for the detection of CEA rely on laboratory-based instrumentation for color, fluorescence, chemiluminescence and even EC measurement. Cellphone (CP)-based technologies with smart applications are a new trend in bioanalytical applications. A compact colorimetric and fluorometric reader, as well as a CP-based compact EC sensing platform, have been reported. Indeed, it is feasible for colorimetric readout from a 96-well MTP using a CP device and the measurement of a full emission spectrum of any light emitter using a CPbased fluorimeter. Together with graphene as a sensing interface, the CP-platform doubtlessly provides cost-effective mobile healthcare and personalized medicine with widespread applications for POCT. The integration of screen printed graphene electrodes (SPGE) with an enhanced active area with a CP based electrical platform is appealing for POCT or doctor's office in remote areas. Graphene can be used to modify carbon-based screen printed electrodes and such products are also commercially available. Lastly, the clinical significance of CEA deserves a brief comment here as the clinicians begin monitoring CEA levels in the cancer patients before the treatment to establish a baseline amount. The test will be repeated during and after treatment to assess changes over time. CEA levels often return to normal between one and four months after the tumors had been successfully removed. However, the CEA test is not useful in screening the general population for cancer. CEA monitoring in cancer patients, in particular, patients with colorectal cancer, is still controversial, which may vary from bimonthly monitoring to no monitoring in the surveillance setting (for stage I-III disease) and there are no clear guidelines in the metastatic setting. CEA monitoring in patients with other types of cancer, such as breast, lung, stomach, pancreas, ovary, bladder, thyroid and liver, is still unclear or debatable. Future endeavors may benefit from evaluating CEA with other biomarkers to create a more precise index for cancer prognosis and recurrence. Thus, CEA might need to be measured with other tumor markers such as human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2, breast cancer cells), prostate-specific antigen (PSA, prostate cancer), cancer antigen 125 (CA 125, ovarian cancer cells), as well as CRP, a general biomarker for inflammation and infection. Conceptually, different capture antibodies can still be anchored on the same interface, however, second antibodies need to be conjugated with probes with different electrochemical or optical properties. Finally, there is also a need to devise and validate prospective multiplexing strategies, enabling the precise determination of CEA in a sample together with such biomarkers. With the improved diagnosis, specific treatment can be offered to the patients to attain better treatment outcome. In summury, some of nanomaterial-based immunosensors for CEA are comprehensively discussed in this review. More importantly, different aspects of the immunosensors such as type of nanomaterial, injection and detection method, labels, signal amplificators and the corresponding sample matrix, the sensitivity, etc. are discussed in detail. Consequently, several outstanding properties of the immunosensors and their research opportunities as well as the development potential and prospects are discussed. Additionally, we summarized examples of nanomaterial-based immunosensors reported so far in the literature, with their advantages and limitations and stress their potential for future developments in this field. Importantly, the use of nanomaterial would most likely result in enhanced analytical characteristics of the CEA immunosensors, particularly with respect to operational stability, life-time, and operation in harsh conditions. The presence of diffusion barriers and possible antigen entrapping are major limitations, resulting in high response times and instability problems. Even though several strategies are available to avert entrapping, these are generally complex and poorly reproducible, involving multiple processing steps prior to antibody immobilization. Furthermore, their successful use in immunosensors is strongly dependent on how efficient the antigen-dendrimers assembly is attached on to the physical transducer surface and the homogeneity of the dendrimer layer.

While reported results are exciting and exhibit great potential for future applications, new breakthroughs are still required for CEA immunosensing. For example, many of the new immunosensors built have not yet been investigated in vivo, so important information regarding circulation properties in blood and accumulation in liver or other tissues needs to be acquired, and eventual problems emerging from those studies will need to be addressed. Although the fast advancement of immunosensors highlights their future applications in diverse scientific fields, the major impacts of such technologies appear to be in early detection of cancer. Of these applications, early detection of cancer seems to provide an interesting approach for the development of novel target-based therapies (e.g., using electrochemical/photonic and photoelectrochemical probes for detection of CEA). Since many of these immunosensors have been only developed in laboratory so far, it will be a major challenge to introduce a technology allowing rapid production of large numbers of sensors with relatively low cost and high quality specifications. Such technology is prerequisite for any successful commercial application. At the end of this review, it is worth mentioning that nanomaterial based immunosensors can be used as quantitative analytical tools for detection of CEA in different cancers. The immunosensors is competitive with ELISA.
4. Future prospects Also, we have featured some recent advances in dendrimer-NP hybrids for electrochemical biosensors. The introduction of the dendrimer-NP hybrid systems with unique tailored functions implants their novel functions into electrochemical sensing interfaces, resulting in the fabrication of many novel high-sensitivity biosensors. The future outlook for the field is bright and promising. As we showed above, the unique properties of Au NPs, hyperbranch nanopolymers, graphen and graphen quantum dots, and upconversation NPs, have led to simple, highly-sensitive, analytical procedures that can not be accomplished by standard methods. However, the preparation of more novel and sensitive immunosensors will largely depend on rapid progress in the synthesis of new materials with unique shapes and structures. So, much effort needs to be devoted to functionalization of above discussed nanomaterials with unique shapes and structures. The fast advancement of nanomaterial based immunosensors highlights their future applications in CEA detection, the major impacts of such technologies appear to be in early detection of cancer. Also, electrochemical/photoelectrochemical immunosensors based on nanomaterials provide fast, simple, sensitive detection systems for CEA realated cancers that may provide robust tools for anticancer sensors research. We predict a bright future for electriochemical and optical immunosensing of CEA constracted based on nanomaterials because of their biocompatibility, high conductivity, and abundance of inexpensive source material and so on. We should also mention here that there is no comparison of robustness of the above discussed immunosensors with gold standard methods such as ELISA in the literature. Obviously, scientistes have a great deal to do to address nanosized-immunosensors for CEA in the future. In general, different typr of immunoensors based on nanomaterials show great promise for future applications in heath-care testing, disease diagnostics and CEA monitoring in paitent. Therefore, there is no doubt that they will have major impact on point-of-care clinical diagnostics, decentralized genetic testing, and real time monitoring of CEA in real samples. Therefore, nanomaterial-based immunosensors have great potential to create the next generation of CEA immunosensors due to their unique structural, electrical and mechanical properties. We hope that this overview has illustrated that nanomaterial-based immunosensors have achieved considerable success in the academic and that the need for new, easy-to-use, home and decentralised diagnostics of CEA is greater than ever.

CEA is one of the most widely used tumor markers in the clinical diagnosis of breast, colorectal, and lung cancer making monitoring of CEA very important for clinical tumor diagnoses [82].
Recently, upconverting nanoparticles were used in development of a new sandwich-type immunoassay for the quantification of CEA using fluorescence spectroscopy [83].
[84] reported an aptasensor for CEA determination using upconversion phosphors (UCPs) and carbon nanoparticles (CNPs) on the basis of fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET).
A graphene sheet can be used to coat an Au SPR chip to increase the adsorption of biomolecules [85].
